title: Imposes criminal penalties for death or serious injury of individuals resulting from violations of the multiple dwelling law
summary: Imposes criminal penalties for death or serious injury of individuals resulting from violations of the multiple dwelling law; class D felony for criminal negligent death.

       AN ACT to amend the penal law,  in  relation  to  establishing  criminal
         negligence  for  individuals who violate or assist in the violation of
         any provision of the multiple dwelling law where  such  violation  has
         resulted  in  the death of another; and to amend the multiple dwelling
         law, in relation to increasing the penalties for persons  who  violate
         or  assist  in the violation of any provision of the multiple dwelling
         law where such violation has resulted in serious physical injury

         THE PEOPLE OF THE STATE OF NEW YORK, REPRESENTED IN SENATE AND  ASSEM-
       BLY, DO ENACT AS FOLLOWS:

    1    Section  1.  The first undesignated paragraph of section 125.10 of the
    2  penal law is amended to read as follows:
    3    A person is guilty of criminally negligent homicide when[,]:
    4    1. with criminal negligence, he OR SHE causes  the  death  of  another
    5  person; OR
    6    2. A  PERSON  VIOLATES OR ASSISTS IN THE VIOLATION OF ANY PROVISION OF
    7  THE MULTIPLE DWELLING LAW AND SUCH VIOLATION HAS RESULTED IN  THE  DEATH
    8  OF ANOTHER.
    9    S  2.  Section 304 of the multiple dwelling law is amended by adding a
   10  new subdivision 1-b to read as follows:
   11    1-B. EVERY PERSON WHO SHALL VIOLATE OR ASSIST IN THE VIOLATION OF  ANY
   12  PROVISION OF THIS CHAPTER AND WHERE SUCH VIOLATION CREATES SERIOUS PHYS-
   13  ICAL  INJURY TO ANOTHER PERSON SHALL BE GUILTY OF A MISDEMEANOR PUNISHA-
   14  BLE BY A FINE NOT EXCEEDING TWO THOUSAND DOLLARS OR BY IMPRISONMENT  FOR
   15  A PERIOD NOT EXCEEDING ONE YEAR, OR BY BOTH SUCH FINE AND IMPRISONMENT.
   16    S 3. This act shall take effect on the first of November next succeed-
   17  ing the date on which it shall have become a law.

memo:
BILL NUMBER:S2127

TITLE OF BILL:
An act
to amend the penal law, in relation to establishing criminal negligence
for individuals who violate or assist in the violation of any provision
of the multiple dwelling law where such violation has resulted in the
death of another; and to amend the multiple dwelling law,
in relation to
increasing the penalties for
persons who violate or assist in the violation of any provision of the
multiple dwelling law where such violation has resulted in serious
physical injury

PURPOSE:
This bill amends the Penal Law and the Multiple Dwelling Law, imposing
criminal penalties for death or serious injury of individuals
resulting from violations of the multiple dwelling law.

SUMMARY OF PROVISIONS:
Current law does not provide specific criminal penalties for
violations of the Multiple Dwelling Law where such violations result
in death or serious physical injury.

Section 1 of this bill amends section 125.10 of the penal Law by
adding a section that finds a person guilty of criminally negligent
homicide when a person violates or assists in the violation of any
provision of the multiple dwelling law and such violation results in
the death of another.

Section 2 of this bill amends section 304 of the Multiple Dwelling Law
by adding a new subdivision 1-b that provides that every person who
violates or assists in the violation of any provision of the multiple
dwelling law, where such violation results in serious physical injury
to another person shall be guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by a
fine not exceeding two thousand dollars or by imprisonment for a
period not exceeding one year, or by both.

EXISTING LAW:
Current provisions of the multiple dwelling law do not provide
enhanced penalties for violations where such violations result in
serious physical harm; the penal law does not provide specific
charges where violations of the multiple dwelling law result in death.

JUSTIFICATION:
The problem of illegal apartment conversions is persistent and
pervasive, and places residents of the State in danger of physical
harm or
death, and puts tremendous strains on community resources, including
building, fire and emergency medical services personnel. An illegal
conversion is the creation of one or more additional dwelling units

within a building without first receiving the necessary building
permits.

On May 7, 2007, a Brooklyn fire claimed the life of a mother and her
one year old son, critically injuring two other family members. The
illegally converted basement apartment had no smoke detectors and the
rear exit was sealed shut, according to the New York City Fire
Department.

This bill also provides District Attorneys with the ability to present
a charge for criminally negligent homicide where violations of the
multiple dwelling law results in the death of another. Current
provisions of the penal law do not contain a specific section
addressing such a crime.

Also, current provisions of the multiple dwelling law do not
criminalize violations of that section, regardless of the harm
resulting from such violations. Under existing law, violations are
punishable based not upon the severity of the resulting injury, but
are graduated depending on the number of offenses. This bill
recognizes that an illegal conversion is a serious offense, and
provides enhanced penalties for those who violate, or assist in
violating the multiple dwelling law where serious physical injury
occurs as a result of such violations.

LEGISLATIVE HISTORY:
New bill.

FISCAL IMPLICATIONS:
There would be no fiscal impact.

LOCAL FISCAL IMPLICATIONS:
There would be no local fiscal impact.

EFFECTIVE DATE:
This act shall take effect on the first of November next succeeding
the date on which it shall have become a law.
